subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] To Paul
msgSnippet: I agree that Spelling Pronunciation is to be avoided when we are writing with a different alphabet. What I m trying to avoid is the sinking of unaccented
messageBody:
I agree that Spelling Pronunciation is to be
avoided when we are writing with a different alphabet.
What I'm trying to avoid is the sinking of
unaccented vowels to minor variations of schwa, which
I notice in my own and others' speech when being
careless and casual.

Do you have another way of distinguishing the
vowels than Citation?

I'm asking because I've completed the excellent
Alice in Wonderland progressive reading tutorial, and
am ready to start writing in QS. I want to do it
right, as far as my ear and brain will allow.

--- Paul Vandenbrink <pvandenbrink11@...>
wrote:
> Hi Tiny
> The problem with using Citation Pronunciation
> to write with the Read Alphabet
> is that pronunciation is dependant on a literary
> understanding
> of English and is derived from the Roman letter
> spelling of
> the English word.
> The whole point of the Read Alphabet is that it is a
> replacement
> for the Roman Alphabet, not just an adjunct or
> shorthand.
>
> Let's go back to an actual nice clear English
> pronunciation,
> not some
> ideal pronunciation based on the old Roman Letter
> spelling.
> I'd rather figure out a consistent accent, than an
> archaic
> spelling.
> Regards, Paul V.


===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein
